Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of bearded man wearing pointed cap, helmet or conical headdress with chin-strap. Mould-made from a two-piece mould and hollow. Red slip (?). Red-brown Nile silt fabric, with abundant mica and sand inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Three similar examples from Naukratis (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA703; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4722 and in an earlier style, but of the same subject AN1886.486). Resembles Late Period riders, but in later Ptolemaic style of construction. Similar piece from Memphis (Petrie 1909a, pl. 42, no. 55). Late 4th to early 3rd century BC parallel from Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, no. 174). Late 3rd century BC parallel (Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.468) Bayer Niemeier , E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch- römische Terrakotten, Melsungen. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1909, Memphis I, London. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.343) (Phase 3)
